w:r.w:t: The student will learn to discuss their likes and dislikes. They will also be able to indicate their favorites and least favorites. Students will be encouraged to respond openly and in complete sentences. Learning how to express their opinions will help them in everyday conversation.
At the completion of this lesson, students will be able to:
Recognize, spell, and pronounce target words associated with likes and dislikes
Use these sets of words in complete sentences
Students will be able to describe what
they like and don’t like and their favorite and least favorite things
This slide will always be the
-branded opener slide that the teacher will display as the student enters the classroom.
Greet your student and introduce the lesson concept: “Today, we are going to be learning about likes and dislikes.”
Visual cue: If needed review the types of classes by writing on your whiteboard, holding up books etc.
Using TPR to indicate a question.
For extension ask: “What is your favorite class?” Indicate favorite by making a heart with your hands.
Circles classes they do not like.
Using TPR to shake your head and thumbs down for dislike.
Ask: What animal do you like? Using TPR to indicate a question.
Ask: Why do you like it?
Ask: Do you have a pet or have you been to the zoo?
Allow the student to respond in complete sentence, asking probing questions if applicable.
Ask: “What animal is your favorite?” With TPR or allow the student to read the question and answer themselves in a complete sentence.
Ask why it is their favorite animal.
Allow them to respond in a complete sentence.
Using TPR ask the student to circle the food they like.
Allow the student to respond in a full sentence.
Extension: Depending on the conversational ability of the student they may
be able to tell you about a time when they ate that food.
Have the student circle the food they don’t like
Visual cue: Show pictures of other food not pictured or real food and ask the student if they like them.
If possible show some interesting foods that they may not have tried to spark conversations.
Draws a picture of a favorite food.
Tells about a time they ate their favorite food.
Have the student briefly draw a picture of a favorite food.
Talk about why it is a favorite food. Ask the student to tell you more about their favorite food or a time they ate it.
Tells about a time they ate their least favorite food, or why it is their least favorite food.
Have the student briefly draw a picture of their least favorite food.
Talk about a time they ate their least favorite food, or why it is their least favorite food.
Ask the student using TPR: “Do you like to watch movies?”
Ask if they like to go to the movie theatre – using TPR to indicate going somewhere.
Follow- up with: “Do you like to watch TV?”
Circles the types of movies they like.
Draws an X on the movies they don’t like.
Ask the student: “What movies do you like?” Using TPR
Have the student circle what they like.
Have the student put an X on what they don’t like.
“I like to eat_____ when I go to the movies.”
Allow the student to read the question out loud.
If they say they don’t know, ask them if they like to eat while they are watching TV or a movie.
“Do you like to play games?” Using TPR
Visual cue: Show the student board games or a video game console.
Ask probing questions to extend about what types of games they like to play.
Circles their favorite sport or tells the teacher about another sport they like if it is not pictured.
tudent to circle their favorite sport or tell you about it if not pictured.
Show pictures of other sports and go over the names of the sports.
Ask: “Do you like to play it or watch it?” Using TPR for play and watch.
Circles their least favorite sport or tells the teacher about another sport they don’t like if it is not pictured.
Ask: “What is your least favorite sport?”
Allow the student to respond in a full sentence a
nd circle their least favorite, or talk about another sport they don’t like.
Answer the teacher’s questions in complete sentences.
Allow the student to respond and
them to tell you why they like it
Visual cue: Show other pictures of hobbies.
Allow the student to respond and tell why they don’t like it.
Ask: “What is your favorite season?” Using TPR (thumps up)
Ask: “What is your least favorite season?” Using TPR (thumbs down)
Ask student to fill in the blanks.
Encourage them to read each word.
Extension: Have the student use each word in a sentence.
Use this blank slide space to practice spelling, or writing sentences about their likes and dislikes.
Have them draw something they love to do and tell you about it.
Word Wall Vocabulary Builder Activity – Slide 22
will read and spell their new words
The teacher will give feedback on the spelling and pronunciation of the new words.
Choose several words to create a sentence
